contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "yourself" is a reflexive pronoun. Alternate translation: "Come home with me and eat some food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.glQuote: Come home with me and refresh yourself

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "himself" is used to emphasize that he was alone. Alternate translation: "he walked by himself for a day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.glQuote: he himself went a day's journey

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words "I" and "myself" refer to Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I will save from death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])

The word "himself" indicates that Elisha was plowing with the last yoke, while other men were plowing with the other eleven yokes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: he himself was plowing with the twelfth yoke
